clusters.title: AI Awareness
clusters.description: A significant portion of Americans, 90%, have some awareness of AI, with 33% having heard a lot about it and 56% a little. Despite this awareness, there are mixed feelings about AI's integration into daily life. While 36% feel a mix of excitement and concern, 52% are more concerned than excited. Among those well-informed about AI, concern outweighs excitement by significant margins, with 32 percentage points more concerned among those who've heard a lot and 50 points among those who've heard a little.

clusters.title: AI Healthcare
clusters.description: A significant majority, 68%, anticipate that ethical principles focused on the public good will not be used in most AI systems by 2030, while 32% believe they will. In healthcare, 60% of U.S. adults feel uncomfortable with AI, despite 38% expecting better health outcomes. Concerns include AI's impact on patient-provider relationships, with 57% fearing it will worsen. However, 51% believe AI could reduce bias in healthcare. Additionally, three-quarters of Americans worry about the rapid adoption of AI by healthcare providers. Notably, a project has successfully used AI to predict SIDS with 94% accuracy.

merged_facts.merged_content: Perceptions of AI in healthcare outcomes: 38% believe AI would lead to better health outcomes, 33% believe it would lead to worse outcomes, and 27% believe it would make no difference. This is based on a survey conducted by Pew Research Center from Dec. 12-18, 2022.

related_facts.fact_group_content: 52% of Americans are more concerned than excited about AI in daily life.
37% of Americans are more concerned than excited about the increased use of AI in everyday life.
19% of Americans who are more concerned than excited about AI express concerns about job loss.
16% of those more concerned about AI are worried about privacy problems, surveillance, or hacking.
12% of respondents are concerned about dehumanization due to AI.
24% more Americans with a high school education or less are concerned about AI performing repetitive workplace tasks compared to those with postgraduate degrees (36% vs. 12%).
38% of Americans were mostly concerned about AI in daily life in December 2022.
Gap between concern and excitement among adults ages 65 and older is 57 percentage points.
53% of Americans say AI is doing more to hurt than help people keep their personal information private.
10% of Americans are more excited than concerned about AI in daily life.
18% of Americans are more excited than concerned about the increased use of AI in everyday life.
53% of Americans say AI is doing more to hurt than help people keep their personal information private.
10% of Americans say AI helps more than it hurts in keeping personal information private.
37% of Americans aren't sure about AI's impact on privacy.
500 hours of video content are posted to YouTube every minute.

clusters.title: AI Privacy
clusters.description: The majority of Americans express concern over AI's impact on daily life, with 52% more concerned than excited and only 10% more excited than concerned. Concerns include job loss (19%), privacy issues (16%), and potential misuse of AI (8%). There is a significant concern about AI's impact on privacy, with 53% believing it hurts more than helps. Differences in concern levels are observed across educational and age groups, with older adults showing a larger gap between concern and excitement.

merged_facts.merged_content: Americans' feelings towards AI in daily life are varied, with significant proportions of concern, excitement, and mixed emotions.
